Expectation1: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation1: Thunderstorm cells force multiple flights to reroute, increasing handoffs between sectors.
Expectation2: Participate in community rituals and ceremonies
Situation2: The monastery’s once-a-year festival begins at dawn and needs committed volunteers for preparations.
Story: The radar screen glowed with a frantic energy, blips multiplying as thunderstorm cells forced pilots to request new headings. My headset crackled with voices—colleagues in adjacent sectors, pilots anxious for guidance, the whole system straining under the pressure. I was supposed to coordinate handoffs, keep the airspace flowing, prevent chaos. Every second, a new decision, a new responsibility. Yet, in the back of my mind, the monastery bell tolled. Today was the festival, the one day each year when the community gathered before sunrise, chanting, preparing offerings, weaving garlands. I had promised to help, to be present, to embody the calm and compassion my practice demanded. But here I was, tethered to my console, heart racing, torn between the urgent needs of the sky and the quiet call of the sangha. The expectation to be everywhere at once pressed down on me, and I felt the storm inside grow as fierce as the one outside.
